bioghist.p: George T. Reynolds (1917-2005) was a leading research director in the fields of cosmic rays, high energy particle physics, and biophysics. Reynolds graduated from Rutgers University in 1939 and earned his Ph.D. from Princeton in 1943. During World War II, Reynolds worked on the Manhattan Project as a blast effect specialist and was sent to Japan to conduct bomb damage analysis. He returned to Princeton in 1946 as an assistant professor, and by 1959 he was a full professor. He gained emeritus status in 1987. From 1948 to 1970, Reynolds was director of the High Energy Physics Program at Princeton. Reynolds' later research focused on applying image intensification techniques to biological observations, including bioluminescence and X-ray diffraction. This work led to an appointment as a member of the Corporation of the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, where he was a principal investigator during the course of 31 summers. He was also an adjunct scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of George T. Reynolds, much of it related to his work on image intensification techniques. Materials include: technical reports, research proposals, dissertations, reprints and drafts of articles by Reynolds and others; subject files on topics within physics and other branches of science; proposals, reports, and financial records for grants from the National Science Foundation, the Department of Energy, and other funding organizations; lab notes; notes and programs for conferences and symposia; problem sets and questions for senior comprehensive examinations at Princeton; and photographs, negatives, slides, and technical drawings.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
